components.html:
A Knowledge Integration Lesson

Curriculum authors: This sequence guides you to build a four-step lesson, in which each step engages students in a knowledge integration process.

  1. Generate ideas
  2. Discover new ideas
  3. Distinguish among initial ideas and the new ideas you discovered
  4. Connect ideas

We have provided a possible step you could use to guide your students in each of these processes. You can edit the step we provided, or delete it and make your own using the + button above.

Delete this introductory text once you are done and have fun designing!

What do we know about [insert topic]?



Introduce the topic you would like students to brainstorm about...


This step provides a class discussion where students can brainstorm their ideas about a topic.

  1. Edit the introductory text above to introduce a topic you"d like students to brainstorm about.
  2. Then edit the prompt for the discussion component below.
  3. Delete this help text when you're finished.

components.prompt: [Customize prompt] What do you already know about XXXX? Post your ideas to the share them with the class!

components.html:
What do you already know?




Introduce the topic you want students to think about...


This step provides a "labeling" activity where students can annotate an image with what they know now.

  1. Edit the introductory text above to introduce the topic you want students to think about.
  2. Add a background image for students to label with their initial ideas about the topic.
  3. Upload your own image by clicking the  (choose an image) button.
  4. 3. Edit the prompt for the label activity below.
  5. 4. Delete this help text when you"re finished.

components.prompt:
[Customize prompt] Click on the labels below to add two ideas you have about XXXX.

Click the + button to add more ideas.

Add as many labels as you have ideas!

components.html:
Exploring a Model


Introduce the model, simulation, or other OER you want students to investigate...


This step provides students with an opportunity to explore a model, simulation, video, or some other open educational resource (OER).

  1. Edit the step title and text above to introduce the resource you want students to engage with.
  2. Select the resource you want students to examine using the Outside Resource component below. [Note: if you would like to use an offline activity or other resource, include instructions for accessing the resource above and feel free to delete the Outside Resource component.]
  3. Edit the prompt for the open response component at the end of the step to help students explain or describe their new ideas.
  4. Delete this help text when you're finished.

components.prompt: [Customize prompt] Use evidence from the model to explain... I observed... I noticed... I wonder...

components.html:
Explanation and Peer Feedback 


Introduce the task here...


This step asks students to generate an explanation of something they observe in the model, simulation, video, or other OER in the previous step.

  1. Students share their explanation to a class discussion and provide feedback to a peer(s) with an idea that is different from their own. 
  2. Edit the introductory text above to outline the explanation and discussion task you want students to engage in.
  3. Customize the discussion prompt.
  4. Delete this text when you are finished.

components.prompt: Customize prompt such as ... Use evidence from the model to explain why... how...

components.html:
Help your peers revise!

Find a peers' explanation that is different than yours. Explain to them how you two are thinking differently about the topic and what idea you suggest they consider.


This task requires students to scroll back up to the discussion and comment on their peers' explanations.

  1. Customize the introductory text above to describe the peer feedback task you want students to engage in. Students can comment on one or more peer explanations to distinguish between how they and their peer are thinking about what they observed in the model, simulation, video, or other OER.
  2. Students often decide to give rather general comments such as "I like your idea" or "this is a nice idea". In your instructions, help students engage in giving helpful (constructive and critical) feedback.
  3. Delete this text when you are finished.

title: Distinguish Ideas: Help your peers revise their ideas!

components.html:
Sorting ideas


Introduce the task here...


This step asks students to sort ideas into different categories.

  1. Edit the introductory text above to outline the sorting task you want students to engage in.
  2. Add "Choices" to the Match component below. These will be the ideas students will have to sort.
  3. Customize the name for the "Choices" bucket. These are the categories (buckets) in which students will drag the choices to.
  4. Optional: In the "Feedback" section, you can mark which containers are correct for each of the choices and/or add feedback text the students will see when they submit their answers.
  5. Delete this help text when you're finished.

Revise your explanation


What have you learned now that you explored...?


This step imports prior work and asks students to revise their previous explanation or ideas. Edit the introductory text above to outline the revision task you want students to engage in.


To select the previous work for students to revise:

  1. Click on the  (advanced) button for the Open Response Component below.
  2. Scroll to "Connected Components" and choose the Step and Component that contains the work you want to students to review.
  3. For the "Type" option, select "Import Work".
  4. Note: If you would like to have students revise a different type of work, you can delete the Open Response component and add the type of component you"d like by clicking the "Add New Component" button above. Then follow the same steps to import work.

Next:

  1. Customize the prompt for the imported work component below.
  2. Delete this help text when you"re finished.

components.prompt: [Customize prompt] Here is what you said earlier... Revise based on what you've learned by exploring...

components.html:
Convince Me!



Two students are having a debate about...

This step is meant to engage students in an argument.ï»¿
  1. Create either: 1) a debate between two students about the science topic you are teaching, or 2) a fictitious peers' argument.
  2. The fictitious peers' arguments can either be incorrect or missing a key idea.
  3. Ask students to weigh in on who they think is right in the debate or whether they think their peer's argument is correct and why. Make sure to encourage students to include evidence from the unit to add, correct, or counter the presented argument/debate.
  4. Add the contents of the debate or the peer's argument above and then edit the prompt for the Open Response component below.
  5. Delete this help text when you're finished.

components.prompt: [Customize prompt] Who do you think is right and why? Do you think XXXX's argument is correct? Why or why not?

components.html:
Help Mia!




Mia has some great ideas about... But she needs some help solving a problem...


  1. This step asks students to use what they've learned to help someone with a problem related to what students have been learning in this unit.
  2. Create a story about a fictitious peer or character who needs help solving a problem or completing a task. Edit the introductory text above to introduce the task.
  3. At this point, it is important that students are asked to think about they variety of aspects they have explore for this topic and integrate these in their explanation or solution.
  4. Write your story about and then edit the prompt for the Open Response component below.
  5. Delete this help text when you're finished.

components.prompt: [Customize prompt] Explain to Mia... How can Mia...? Be sure to include ideas about...
